FRBRname.value: Marilyn Freda Knatchbull-Hugessen v SISU Capital Limited

TLCOrganization.showAs: The Queen's Bench Division of the High Court

p.courtType: IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE

header.p: Rhodri Thompson QC & Christopher Brown for the Defendants

content.p: The claim and counterclaim in this case arise out of commercial negotiations which did not result in aÂ concluded agreement. They are claims by the claimants and defendant respectively to recover professional fees and other expenses incurred in or in connection with those abortive negotiations. The negotiations formed part of an attempt by the owners of CoventryÂ City Football Club (âthe Clubâ) to find aÂ solution to serious financial difficulties which in 2012 had brought the Club to the brink of insolvency.

The Club was owned by aÂ company inÂ the SISUÂ group of companies, being aÂ group of companies whose investments are managed by the defendant in this case, SISUÂ Capital Limited (âSISUâ). The Club's home ground atÂ the time was the RicohÂ Arena in Coventry. The arena was operated by Arena Coventry Limited (âACLâ). ACL was owned indirectly in equal shares by the claimants in this case who are the four Trustees of the AlanÂ Edward Higgs Charity (whom IÂ shall refer to as "the Trustees" or "the Charity") and CoventryÂ City Council.

ACL had borrowed aÂ very substantial sum of the order of Â£22Â million from ClydesdaleÂ Bank plc trading as YorkshireÂ Bank in order to fund the acquisition of aÂ lease of the arena. The Club had aÂ licence to use the arena, granted by aÂ wholly owned subsidiary of ACL. ACL was dependent on the revenue from this licence to service its debt to YorkshireÂ Bank.

In MarchÂ 2012, SISU embarked on negotiations to try to rescue the Club from its financial difficulties. At the same time the Club stopped making payments of licence fees to the ACL subsidiary. One element of the negotiations was aÂ proposal by SISU to acquire the Charity's 50 perÂ cent interest inÂ the share capital of ACL. Discussions reached the stage where SISU and the Charity were able to agree indicative terms for such aÂ share purchase, which were recorded in aÂ document dated 18Â JuneÂ 2012, described as an indicative term sheet.

This term sheet outlined aÂ proposed transaction whereby "SISU or another SISUÂ Group company" would purchase the Charity's 50 perÂ cent interest in ACL for aÂ total cash consideration of Â£1.5Â million, payable immediately upon completion of the share purchase.

Following completion, it was envisaged that whatÂ was in effect further deferred consideration would be payable over aÂ period of ten years. The mechanism for this proposed by SISU was the allocation to the Charity of preferred equity in ACL for aÂ value of Â£4Â million, which would be paid down through annual payments over the ten-year period. However, this proposal was not set in stone. The term sheet contained aÂ statement that:
"SISU would consider an alternative structure to that of preferred equity. The parties will work together to achieve aÂ solution in respect of suitable alternatives."

The term sheet further recorded that SISU would require aÂ period for due diligence investigations, which was expected to last 30Â days. Four conditions precedent to completion were indicated, the first of which was that completion would only take place:
"once aÂ transaction has been satisfactorily agreed between ClydesdaleÂ Bank plc trading as YorkshireÂ Bank and SISU."

There were provisions concerning costs and exclusivity, which are atÂ the heart of this case and which IÂ will come back to. The expected closing date for the transaction was said to be "as soon as possible".
There was then aÂ paragraph which stated:

"This offer [meaning the offer made by SISU to purchase shares] is non-binding and subject to due diligence, save for the paragraphs related to Costs and Exclusivity, which shall become immediately binding upon both SISU and the Charity upon countersignature of this term sheet by the Charity, notwithstanding that the remaining terms of this letter remain subject to execution and completion of formal legal agreements."
The term sheet was countersigned on behalf of all the Charity Trustees on 19Â JuneÂ 2012.

It follows that the only two parts of the term sheet which were intended to have contractual effect were the provisions relating to costs and exclusivity. When IÂ refer to "the contract", IÂ shall therefore be referring to those provisions and only those provisions of the term sheet. They stated as follows:

"Costs. SISU acknowledges that the Charity will incur significant costs, fees and expense in evaluating SISU's offer to purchase the shares, and in negotiating the transaction with SISU and its advisors. Accordingly, in the event that SISU withdraws its offer to purchase the shares, or the Charity withdraws from negotiations as a result of SISU seeking a reduction in the purchase price or seeking unreasonable terms, or the Conditions Precedent cannot be met ('Aborted Transaction'), SISU agrees to underwrite and be responsible for all the Charity's reasonable costs and expenses (including without limitation the legal and other professional costs of PwC, Bates Wells & Braithwaite LLP and Gateley LLP and all expenses and associated VAT) incurred up to the point of a transaction with Clydesdale Bank plc, to a maximum of Â£29,000. Underwriting of further costs will be agreed once the transaction has progressed beyond discussions with Clydesdale Bank plc.

Exclusivity. The parties have agreed to a period of exclusivity, commencing on the date of signing of this agreement and ending 6 weeks later (the 'Exclusivity Period'). The Charity undertakes that during the Exclusivity Period it shall (i) only allow SISU to conduct due diligence investigations in relation to ACL; and (ii) conduct negotiations with SISU in good faith with a view to agreeing and executing the legal agreements within the Exclusivity Period.

The Charity undertakes that, during the Exclusivity Period, it shall not, directly or indirectly, enter into, re-start, solicit, initiate or otherwise participate in any third party negotiations, or supply or otherwise disclose any information about ACL to a third party that wishes, or may wish, to enter into third party negotiations (unless the information is publicly available)."

The Exclusivity Period expired on 31Â JulyÂ 2012 without any share purchase agreement being concluded. There was no agreement to extend the Exclusivity Period. No share purchase agreement has ever been concluded.

This action has been brought by the Charity to recover expenses from SISU inÂ the maximum amount permitted by the contract of Â£29,000 on the ground that the conditions precedent cannot be met. The Charity contends that this became so when, inÂ JanuaryÂ 2013, ACL repaid its loan from YorkshireÂ Bank with the assistance of funding from CoventryÂ City Council, with the result that it became impossible for aÂ transaction to be agreed between YorkshireÂ Bank and SISU.

SISU denies that itÂ is liable to pay the costs claimed or any costs incurred by the Charity. SISU has also advanced aÂ counterclaim. This counterclaim is for damages for breach of an alleged implied term of the contract. The alleged implied term is pleaded in paragraphÂ 31 of SISU's draft amended statement of case as follows:

"It was an implied contractual term of the agreement â¦ that the parties would conduct the negotiations in good faith and, in particular, that the claimants would not do anything (or procure that anything be done by any other party or parties) to render impossible or materially to impede the performance of the conditions precedent set out at paragraphÂ 9 of the Defence."

The implied term for which SISU contends has two limbs and the allegations of breach likewise fall into two categories. First, itÂ is alleged that the Charity Trustees acted in aÂ way which rendered compliance with the conditions precedent impossible or materially impeded their performance. Second, itÂ is alleged that, as from 17Â AugustÂ 2012, the Trustees resolved or elected to proceed with an alternative scheme under whichÂ (a) the debt owed by ACL to YorkshireÂ Bank would be assumed by CoventryÂ City Council and not by SISU, but at the same timeÂ (b) the Trustees would keep negotiations with SISU open. ItÂ is said that proceeding in this way without informing SISU of their "true decision(s), plan(s), objective(s) and/or motive(s)" was aÂ breach of the implied obligation to conduct negotiations with SISU in good faith.

The counterclaim alleges that costs have been incurred relating to the proposed transaction envisaged by the term sheet, amounting in total to some Â£290,000. Those costs were incurred not by the defendant company, but by other companies inÂ the SISUÂ group. An application has been made to add those companies as additional parties to the counterclaim on the ground that the defendant was acting as their agent in entering into the contract with the Charity or, alternatively, that they have rights of action under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act (1999).

That application to add additional parties is opposed by MrÂ Brennan on behalf of the Charity Trustees, who seeks to attack the counterclaim at its root by arguing that the implied term on which it rests does not exist.

In these circumstances, and as the question whether the alleged term is to be implied raises aÂ short point of contractual interpretation, IÂ took the view that as aÂ matter of case management IÂ should decide that point as aÂ preliminary issue atÂ the start of this trial before any witnesses are called to give evidence. Establishing atÂ the outset whether the counterclaim is built on rock or on sand may affect the shape and size of the trial.

The principles of law which govern the implication of contractual terms are well-known and IÂ need not rehearse them at any length. Since the influential judgment of LordÂ Hoffmann in AttorneyÂ GeneralÂ for Belize v BelizeÂ Telecom [2009] 1 WLR 1988, the process of implication of terms is generally seen as an exercise inÂ the construction of the contract as aÂ whole. The criteria traditionally used are still relevant, namely that the proposed term must be: (1) reasonable and equitable; (2) necessary to give business efficacy to the contract; (3) so obvious that it goes without saying; (4) capable of clear expression; and (5) must not contradict any express term of the contract.
However, as stated by LordÂ Hoffmann in Belize at [27]:

"This list is best regarded not as aÂ series of independent tests which must each be surmounted, but rather as aÂ collection of different ways in which judges have tried to express the central idea that the proposed implied term must spell out what the contract actually means or in which they have explained why they did not think that it did so. The Board has already discussed the significance of 'necessary to give business efficacy' and âgoes without sayingâ. As for the other formulations, the fact that the proposed implied term would be inequitable or unreasonable or contradict what the parties have expressly said or is incapable of clear expression are all good reasons for saying that aÂ reasonable man would not have understood that to be what the instrument meant."

IÂ have mentioned the factual background to the contract. The legal background is equally important. As many prospective house buyers or sellers know to their cost, there is no general duty currently recognised in English law to conduct contractual negotiations in good faith. There is aÂ duty not to misrepresent facts, but there is no duty to disclose facts which itÂ would be material for the other party to negotiations to know, nor is there any constraint in law which prohibits someone from carrying on negotiations with more than one counterparty at the same time without informing them about the existence of the other or others.

By the same token, if aÂ party incurs costs as aÂ result of entering into or pursuing contractual negotiations which do not result in any concluded agreement, those costs as aÂ general rule are not recoverable from the other party to the negotiations even if the negotiations fail because the other party acts unreasonably or concludes an agreement with someone else with whom it has been negotiating without telling the party who has incurred the costs. ThatÂ is the general rule or default position.

ItÂ is open to parties entering into negotiations to depart from that default position by making aÂ binding contract which will regulate their negotiations. Such aÂ contract may impose an obligation not to negotiate with anyone else during aÂ specified period. Notwithstanding the decision of the House of Lords in Walford v Miles [1992] 2 AC 128, itÂ is also now generally accepted that such aÂ contract may impose an obligation on one or both parties to conduct negotiations in good faith, see eg Petromec Inc v Petroleo Brasileiro SA Petrobras (No 3) [2005] EWCA Civ 891, [2006] 1 Lloyd's Rep 121. Such aÂ contract may also confer aÂ right to recover from the other party costs and expenses incurred in negotiations which prove abortive.

The parties in this case made aÂ contract which contained provisions of all those kinds. However, itÂ is important when construing the contract to bear in mind the default position which applies, except to the extent that the parties have agreed otherwise.

As IÂ have indicated, the parties agreed to aÂ period of exclusivity during which the Charity undertook, first, not to negotiate with anyone or allow anyone else to conduct due diligence investigations inÂ relation to ACL other than SISU and, second, to conduct negotiations with SISU in good faith with aÂ view to concluding aÂ legally binding share purchase agreement. In return for that contractual undertaking by the Charity, SISU undertook to reimburse costs incurred by the Charity up to aÂ specified maximum limit if the negotiations failed for any of certain specified reasons.

It seems to me impossible to imply into that agreement an undertaking by the Charity to conduct negotiations with SISU in good faith after the end of the Exclusivity Period. Such aÂ term would be inconsistent with the parties' agreement.

On behalf of SISU, MrÂ Thompson QC disputed that proposition. There is, he submitted, no inconsistency between agreeing to conduct negotiations in good faith during the six-week Exclusivity Period and agreeing to do so for as long as the negotiations continued. ThatÂ is true inÂ the sense that those two obligations could in principle exist in parallel without either contradicting the other. But in circumstances where aÂ party has undertaken to conduct negotiations in good faith for aÂ specified period against the background that inÂ the absence of such an agreement there is no legal duty of good faith in negotiation, the clear and unambiguous meaning of the agreement isÂ that the undertaking is limited to the period specified inÂ the contract and does not extend beyond it.

The contention that aÂ term is to be implied whereby the Charity undertook to conduct negotiations with SISU in good faith after the end of the specified period of sixÂ weeks seems to me as plain aÂ case as there could be of an attempt to rewrite the parties' bargain. If accepted, itÂ would mean that in return for the promise which SISU gave to reimburse certain costs, SISU would get not just the six week period of good faith negotiation which it bargained for, but aÂ longer period which went beyond, indeed potentially far beyond, what it had bargained for.

The argument for this limb of the alleged implied term therefore falls in my view atÂ the first hurdle. Far from being necessary to imply aÂ term that the Charity would conduct negotiations in good faith after the end of the Exclusivity Period, there is in my view no scope inÂ the contract for any such term.

The other limb of the implied term for which SISU contends isÂ that the Charity Trustees would not do anything to render impossible or materially to impede the performance of the conditions precedent. Such an undertaking is said to be implicit inÂ the provision relating to the Charity's costs.

MrÂ Thompson submitted that it cannot have been intended that the Charity should on the one hand be entitled to come after SISU for costs inÂ the event that the conditions precedent could not be met and, on the other hand, at the same time be free to act in aÂ way which rendered it impossible for those same conditions precedent to be met.

IÂ can see some force inÂ that argument when viewed as an argument for construing the last of the three events which gives rise to aÂ liability of SISU to pay costs, namely that "the Conditions Precedent cannot be met" as excluding aÂ situation in which the conditions precedent cannot be met because the Charity prevents them from being met. IÂ express no concluded view on this point and do not consider it further in this judgment because itÂ is not part of the preliminary issue. If the point is aÂ good one, it operates as aÂ potential defence to the Charity's claim.

However, IÂ can see no justification at all for implying into the contract aÂ free-standing obligation on the part of the Charity not to prevent the conditions precedent from being met, which, if broken, would give rise to aÂ liability in damages. That would again be inconsistent with the parties' bargain. ItÂ is clear from the express terms of the contract that the only party which was given aÂ right to recover wasted costs in certain circumstances was the Charity. In return for that right, the Charity gave undertakings limited in time to afford exclusivity to SISU. The contract contains no provision which gives SISU aÂ right to recover costs from the Charity in any circumstances and SISU gave no undertaking with regard to the conduct of negotiations as aÂ quid pro quo for any such right.

ItÂ would furthermore be wholly disproportionate and unreasonable if the consequence of preventing the conditions precedent from being met was not merely to deprive the Charity of the right to recover its own wasted expenditure, limited to aÂ maximum sum of Â£29,000, but was to render the Charity liable to reimburse SISU for its expenses without any limitation in amount. ItÂ would, in my view, require clear words before the contract could be construed as requiring such an unreasonable result. As itÂ is, there are no words in the contract at all which suggest, let alone expressly state, that this was intended.

In short, the attempt to imply out of SISU's promise to reimburse the Charity's costs to aÂ maximum of Â£29,000 in certain circumstances an unstated promise by the Charity to reimburse SISU's costs with no limit in amount in certain circumstances seems to me to be hopeless.

For these reasons, IÂ rule that there was no implied term of the contract of the kind alleged in paragraphÂ 31 of the counterclaim. It follows that the counterclaim must be dismissed and all that remains to be decided at this trial is whether or not the Charity is entitled to succeed in its claim.
